title: 110_hr1318
content: The "Veterans' Benefits Protection Act" repeals the authority for agent or attorney representation in veterans benefits cases before the Department of Veterans Affairs. The "Veterans' Benefits Protection Act" repeals the authority for agent or attorney representation in veterans benefits cases before the Department of Veterans Affairs. Title 38, United States Code, is amended to remove certain sections regarding the Secretary's requirements for individuals seeking recognition under this section. The "Veterans' Benefits Protection Act" removes the authority for agent or attorney representation in veterans benefits cases before the Department of Veterans Affairs. It amends Title 38, United States Code, to eliminate certain sections related to the Secretary's requirements for individuals seeking recognition under this section. The changes include demonstrating good moral character, being in good repute, and being competent to assist claimants in presenting claims. The "Veterans' Benefits Protection Act" removes agent or attorney representation in veterans benefits cases before the Department of Veterans Affairs by amending Title 38, United States Code. It eliminates certain sections related to the Secretary's requirements for individuals seeking recognition under this section. This includes demonstrating good moral character, being in good repute, and being competent to assist claimants in presenting claims. Additionally, the Act repeals modifications to the date for commencement of services in subsection (c) of section 5904. The "Veterans' Benefits Protection Act" removes agent or attorney representation in veterans benefits cases before the Department of Veterans Affairs by amending Title 38, United States Code. It eliminates certain sections related to the Secretary's requirements for individuals seeking recognition under this section. This includes demonstrating good moral character, being in good repute, and being competent to assist claimants in presenting claims. Additionally, the Act repeals modifications to the date for commencement of services in subsection (c) of section 5904. In paragraph (1), changes are made regarding the filing of a notice of disagreement with the Board of Veterans' Appeals. The "Veterans' Benefits Protection Act" removes agent or attorney representation in veterans benefits cases before the Department of Veterans Affairs by amending Title 38, United States Code. It eliminates certain requirements for individuals seeking recognition under this section, including demonstrating good moral character, being in good repute, and being competent to assist claimants in presenting claims. Additionally, changes are made to the date for commencement of services in subsection (c) of section 5904. The "Veterans' Benefits Protection Act" amends Title 38, United States Code by removing agent or attorney representation in veterans benefits cases before the Department of Veterans Affairs. It eliminates certain requirements for individuals seeking recognition and makes changes to the date for commencement of services. The Act also revises procedures for filing disagreements with the Board. The "Veterans' Benefits Protection Act" allows the Board to review fee agreements and order reductions if fees are deemed excessive. Section 5905 is amended to include penalties for direct or indirect actions. The "Veterans' Benefits Protection Act" allows the Board to review fee agreements and order reductions if fees are excessive. Section 5905 is amended to include penalties for soliciting fees except as provided in specific sections. Amendments in the Veterans Benefits, Health Care, and Information Technology Act of 2006 involve repealing certain subsections.
